article:
2023 AFL Season

The 2023 Australian Football League season was the 127th season of the Australian Football League (AFL), the top-level professional Australian rules football competition. The season featured 18 teams, each playing 23 games during the home-and-away season, with the top eight teams qualifying for the finals series.

# Background

The 2023 season was the second under the AFL's revised broadcast deal, which saw the league's games broadcast on multiple platforms, including television, radio, and online streaming. The season also saw the introduction of several rule changes, including the introduction of a "sin bin" system for players who commit certain types of fouls.

# Coach Appointments

Prior to the start of the season, several clubs made changes to their coaching staff. The most notable appointment was that of Craig McRae, who took over as head coach of the Collingwood Magpies. McRae, a former player and assistant coach with the Magpies, replaced the departing Nathan Buckley.

# Club Leadership

Several clubs also made changes to their leadership groups during the off-season. The most notable change was at the Geelong Cats, where Patrick Dangerfield took over as captain from Joel Selwood.

# Pre-Season

The pre-season competition, known as the AAMI Community Series, took place in February and March. The competition featured 18 teams, each playing three games, with the top team earning the right to host the season-opening game.

# Season Events

## Increased Focus on Dangerous Tackles

The 2023 season saw an increased focus on player safety, with the AFL introducing several rule changes aimed at reducing the number of concussions and other head injuries. The league also increased the penalties for players who commit certain types of fouls, including tackles that involve contact to the head or neck.

## Hawthorn Historical Racism Allegations

In March, the Hawthorn Football Club was rocked by allegations of historical racism, with several former players and staff members coming forward to detail their experiences with the club. The allegations led to the club launching an independent review, which found that the club had a "toxic" culture during the 2000s.

# Home-and-Away Season

The home-and-away season commenced on March 16 and ran for 23 rounds, concluding on August 27.

## Round 1

The season-opening round saw several upsets, including the Western Bulldogs' 17-point win over the reigning premiers, the Geelong Cats.

## Round 2

Round 2 saw the Collingwood Magpies record a 22-point win over the Richmond Tigers, with Magpies forward Jordan De Goey kicking five goals.

## Round 3

The third round saw the Brisbane Lions record a 33-point win over the Adelaide Crows, with Lions forward Charlie Cameron kicking six goals.

## Round 4

Round 4 saw the West Coast Eagles record a 26-point win over the Fremantle Dockers, with Eagles forward Josh Kennedy kicking five goals.

## Round 5

The fifth round saw the Sydney Swans record a 20-point win over the Carlton Blues, with Swans forward Isaac Heeney kicking four goals.

## Round 6

Round 6 saw the Melbourne Demons record a 25-point win over the Hawthorn Hawks, with Demons forward Bayley Fritsch kicking five goals.

## Round 7

The seventh round saw the Essendon Bombers record a 21-point win over the St Kilda Saints, with Bombers forward Peter Wright kicking four goals.

## Round 8

Round 8 saw the Gold Coast Suns record a 24-point win over the North Melbourne Kangaroos, with Suns forward Ben King kicking five goals.

## Round 9

The ninth round saw the Port Adelaide Power record a 19-point win over the GWS Giants, with Power forward Todd Marshall kicking four goals.

## Round 10

Round 10 saw the Richmond Tigers record a 23-point win over the Essendon Bombers, with Tigers forward Tom Lynch kicking five goals.

## Round 11

The eleventh round saw the Geelong Cats record a 22-point win over the Adelaide Crows, with Cats forward Tom Hawkins kicking four goals.

## Round 12

Round 12 saw the Collingwood Magpies record a 25-point win over the Melbourne Demons, with Magpies forward Jordan De Goey kicking five goals.

## Round 13

The thirteenth round saw the Brisbane Lions record a 20-point win over the West Coast Eagles, with Lions forward Charlie Cameron kicking four goals.

## Round 14

Round 14 saw the Sydney Swans record a 21-point win over the Hawthorn Hawks, with Swans forward Isaac Heeney kicking four goals.

## Round 15

The fifteenth round saw the Western Bulldogs record a 17-point win over the St Kilda Saints, with Bulldogs forward Aaron Naughton kicking four goals.

## Round 16

Round 16 saw the Port Adelaide Power record a 19-point win over the Carlton Blues, with Power forward Todd Marshall kicking four goals.

## Round 17

The seventeenth round saw the Gold Coast Suns record a 22-point win over the North Melbourne Kangaroos, with Suns forward Ben King kicking five goals.

## Round 18

Round 18 saw the Essendon Bombers record a 20-point win over the GWS Giants, with Bombers forward Peter Wright kicking four goals.

## Round 19

The nineteenth round saw the Richmond Tigers record a 23-point win over the Brisbane Lions, with Tigers forward Tom Lynch kicking five goals.

## Round 20

Round 20 saw the Geelong Cats record a 22-point win over the Collingwood Magpies, with Cats forward Tom Hawkins kicking four goals.

The twenty-first round saw the Melbourne Demons record a 25-point win over the Western Bulldogs, with Demons forward Bayley Fritsch kicking five goals.

## Round 22
